facts.text: Suit property is a Mahal of 84 Bighas 18 Cottas situated within lot Ahiyapur village, part of permanently settled estate of Burdwan Zamindari.
Village granted by Maharaja of Burdwan in Patni settlement to predecessors-in-title of defendants 1 to 7 prior to Bengal Regulation VIII of 1819.
Mahal set apart as Chaukidari Chakaran lands prior to permanent settlement, held by Chaukidars for watchmen services.
Village Chaukidari Act, 1870 (Ben. VI of 1870) passed; s.48 provides transfer of Chaukidari Chakaran lands to zamindar; ss.50-51 detail transfer process subject to prior contracts.
Suit properties transferred to Maharaja of Burdwan in accordance with 1870 Act.

On June 3, 1899, Maharaja granted suit lands to predecessors-in-title of defendants 1 to 7 (who held Patni in lot Ahiyapur) under Exhibit B at yearly rental Rs. 126-8 as., payable partly to Panchayat and balance to Zamindar; default leads to sale under Reg VIII 1819.
Maharaja applied under s.8 Reg VIII 1819 for sale due to arrears; auction on May 15, 1937, purchased by Maharaja himself.
On February 13, 1941, Maharaja granted lands on Patni to appellant/plaintiff.
Appellant filed Title Suit No. 7 of 1946/27 of 1947 in Court of Additional Sub-Judge, 1st Court, Burdwan for ejectment alleging trespass by defendants.
Defendants contested suit alleging no arrears under Exhibit B, sale void.
Sub-Judge (judgment Sept 25, 1948) held arrears due, defendants failed to sue under s.14 Reg within time, decreed for plaintiff.
District Judge, Burdwan (Title Appeal No. 247/16 of 1948, judgment Aug 29, 1950) dismissed appeal: Exhibit B new Patni, sale valid, s.14 bars challenge; no objection to new plea.

Calcutta High Court (Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 971 of 1950, judgment March 21, 1952, Das Gupta and Lahiri JJ.): Exhibit B made lands part of lot Ahiyapur Patni, partial sale void, s.14 inapplicable; dismissed suit.
Supreme Court appeal on certificate under Art. 133(1)(a).

legal_issues.text: Whether the point that Exhibit B incorporated suit lands into lot Ahiyapur Patni making sale invalid as partial sale could be raised first in appeal.
True character of grant under Exhibit B: new distinct Patni or incorporation into existing lot Ahiyapur Patni.
If sale invalid as partial Patni sale, whether s.14 Reg VIII 1819 bars collateral challenge absent timely suit to set aside.

petitioner_arguments.text: Defendants did not raise plea in written statement or trial that Exhibit B made lands part of lot Ahiyapur Patni; should not be allowed in appeal.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Question of law on construction, but surrounding circumstances need evidence

petitioner_arguments.text: Exhibit B creates new distinct Patni; clauses provide for separate sale under Reg VIII 1819 on default.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Construction of document; ut res magis valeat quam pereat; Mohadeb Mundul v. Mr. H. Cowell; Monomothonath Dev v. Mr. G. Glascott

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if invalid as partial tenure sale, defendants must sue under s.14 Reg to set aside within time; cannot collaterally attack.

respondent_arguments.text: No arrears due under Exhibit B; sale void.
Exhibit B incorporates Chaukidari lands as part of lot Ahiyapur Patni; sale of portion illegal.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Clauses linking to lot Ahiyapur; Kanchan Barani Debi v. Umesh Chandra

respondent_arguments.text: Sale void ab initio as partial Patni sale; s.14 Reg inapplicable.

court_reasoning.text: First contention rejected: True nature of Exhibit B is pure question of law on construction; no evidence needed; no objection in District Court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Balkishen Das v. Legge; Maung Kyin v. Ma Shwe La

court_reasoning.text: Rights under s.51 Village Chaukidari Act: Patnidar entitled to lands subject to assessment/share of profits; grant like Exhibit B recognizes right and fixes rent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ranjit Singh v. Maharaj Bahadur Singh; Bhupendra Narayan Singh v. Narapat Singh

court_reasoning.text: Exhibit B construed as new distinct Patni: recital of separate settlement, sale clause on default, transfer/succession provisions; later clauses reconciled as indemnity/cesser on major Patni sale.
court_reasoning.key_observation: ut res magis valeat quam pereat; earlier clauses prevail if conflict (Forbes v. Git); distinguishes Kanchan Barani Debi v. Umesh Chandra

holdings.text: Exhibit B created a new and distinct Patni; sale thereof not invalid as partial Patni sale.

precedents_cited.relevance: No evidence admissible on pure construction of contract/grant

precedents_cited.case_name: Maung Kyin v. Ma Shwe La
precedents_cited.relevance: No evidence on construction unless relating to existing facts

precedents_cited.case_name: Ranjit Singh v. Maharaj Bahadur Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: s.51 saves real rights of Patnidar to Chaukidari lands

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhupendra Narayan Singh v. Narapat Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Zamindar entitled to fair rent on Chaukidari lands in Patni

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohadeb Mundul v. Mr. H. Cowell
precedents_cited.relevance: Separate sanads with sale provisions create distinct Patnis

precedents_cited.case_name: Monomothonath Dev v. Mr. G. Glascott
precedents_cited.relevance: Separate sanads with sale provisions create distinct Patnis

precedents_cited.case_name: Kanchan Barani Debi v. Umesh Chandra
precedents_cited.relevance: Did not consider sale clause effect; similar facts but flawed analysis
Earlier clause prevails over repugnant later clause

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Patni Taluks Regulation, 1819 (Regulation VIII of 1819)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs sale for arrears; time-bar for setting aside sales; applies to distinct Patni

statutes_cited.name: Village Chaukidari Act, 1870 (Ben. VI of 1870)
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer of Chaukidari lands to zamindar subject to prior contracts; basis for Patnidar rights

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, reversed Calcutta High Court judgment, held Exhibit B created new Patni, sale valid; suit for ejectment decreed in favor of appellant.
outcome.relief_granted: Ejectment of defendants from suit lands

key_quotes.text: "Exhibit B properly construed must be held to create a new Patni distinct from lot Ahiyapur, and its sale is therefore valid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on construction of grant

key_quotes.text: "if there be admissible two constructions of a document, one of which will give effect to all the clauses therein while the other will render one or more of them nugatory, it is the former that should be adopted on the principle expressed in the maxim ut res magis valeat quam pereat."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rule of interpretation applied to reconcile clauses

key_quotes.text: "the true nature of the grant under Exhibit B is a matter to be decided on a construction of the terms of the document, and that is a question of law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Allows point in appeal as pure question of law
